Plot: A documentary on Al Gore's campaign to make the issue of global warming a recognized problem worldwide.
Title: An Inconvenient Truth
tomatoConsensus: While global warming is a hotly-debated subject, what everyone on both sides can agree upon is that, if real, it's a very bad thing. Since losing the 2000 presidential election to George W. Bush, former Vice President Al Gore has busied himself by being an outspoken figure against this potential environmental disaster. As much about the man as about greenhouse gases, this candid, powerful and informative documentary illuminates some of the myths surrounding both of its subjects equally well.

Inside Man puts a spin on the Dog Day Afternoon scenario, with a group of sharp bank robbers who stay one step ahead of the police; it's a smart genre film that is not only rewarding on its own terms, but manages to subvert its pulpy trappings with wit and skill.

Lohan's character is supposedly cursed with bad luck, though the movie confuses misfortune with plain stupidity, leading Lohan into a long series of silly and senseless physical gags.

tomatoConsensus: Implausible but entertaining and poignant, Rocky Balboa finds the champ in fighting form for the first time in years.

Plot: A low-ranking thug is entrusted by his crime boss to dispose of a gun that killed corrupt cops, but things get out of control when the gun ends up in wrong hands.
Title: Running Scared
tomatoConsensus: This film runs with frenetic energy punctuated by gratuitous violence but sorely lacks in plot, character development and stylistic flair.

Actors: Annette Bening, Brian Cox, Joseph Fiennes, Evan Rachel Wood
Awards: Nominated for 1 Golden Globe. Another 2 wins & 3 nominations.

Title: Running with Scissors
tomatoConsensus: Despite a few great performances, the film lacks the sincerity and emotional edge of Burroughs' well-loved memoir.

Actors: Robin Williams, Cheryl Hines, Joanna 'JoJo' Levesque, Josh Hutcherson
Plot: Bob Munro and his dysfunctional family rent an RV for a road trip to the Colorado Rockies, where they ultimately have to contend with a bizarre community of campers.
Title: RV
tomatoConsensus: An unoriginal and only occasionally funny family road-trip movie, RV is a mediocre effort that not even the charisma of Robin Williams can save.

Actors: Tim Allen, Elizabeth Mitchell, Eric Lloyd, Judge Reinhold
Plot: Santa, aka Scott Calvin, is faced with double-duty: how to keep his new family happy, and how to stop Jack Frost from taking over Christmas.
Title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause

tomatoConsensus: Playing Jack Frost as an evil cross between Liza Minnelli and Liberace, Martin Short is a welcome presence, but this tired series continues drawing from its bag of bland gags and dumb slapstick.

Actors: Anna Faris, Regina Hall, Craig Bierko, Bill Pullman
Plot: Cindy finds out the house she lives in is haunted by a little boy and goes on a quest to find out who killed him and why. Also, Alien "Tr-iPods" are invading the world and she has to uncover the secret in order to stop them.
Title: Scary Movie 4
Writer: Craig Mazin (screenplay), Jim Abrahams (screenplay), Pat Proft (screenplay), Shawn Wayans (characters), Marlon Wayans (characters), Buddy Johnson (characters), Phil Beauman (characters), Jason Friedberg (characters), Aaron Seltzer (characters)
tomatoConsensus: Sure to inspire a few chuckles, but not enough to compensate for the recycled material from its predecessors.

Actors: Billy Bob Thornton, Jon Heder, Jacinda Barrett, Michael Clarke Duncan

Title: School for Scoundrels
tomatoConsensus: School for Scoundrels squanders its talented cast with a formulaic, unfocused attempt at a romantic comedy that's neither romantic nor funny.

Actors: Gael García Bernal, Charlotte Gainsbourg, Alain Chabat, Miou-Miou
Plot: A man entranced by his dreams and imagination is lovestruck with a French woman and feels he can show her his world.
Title: The Science of Sleep
tomatoConsensus: Lovely and diffuse, Sleep isn't as immediately absorbing as Gondry's previous work, but its messy beauty is its own reward.

Actors: Jim Dunk, Robert Bathurst, Geoff Bell, Christopher Fulford

Title: Scoop
tomatoConsensus: Rehashing old plot lines and characters, Scoop is a tiresome dipper and another disappointing addition to Woody Allen's repertoire.

Actors: Glenn Jacobs, Christina Vidal, Michael J. Pagan, Samantha Noble
Plot: A group of delinquents are sent to clean the Blackwell Hotel. Little do they know reclusive psychopath Jacob Goodnight (Jacobs) has holed away in the rotting hotel. When one of the teens is captured, those who remain -- a group that includes the cop who put a bullet in Goodnight's head four years ago -- band together to survive against the brutal killer.
Title: See No Evil
tomatoConsensus: See No Evil is packed with cliches from countless other teen slasher films, making for a predictable, scare-free waste of time.

Actors: Michael Douglas, Kiefer Sutherland, Eva Longoria, Martin Donovan
Plot: A secret service agent is framed as the mole in an assassination attempt on the president. He must clear his name and foil another assassination attempt while on the run from a relentless FBI agent.
Title: The Sentinel
tomatoConsensus: The Sentinel starts off well enough but quickly wears thin with too many plot holes and conventional action sequences.

Actors: Tim Allen, Kristin Davis, Zena Grey, Spencer Breslin
Plot: A man tries to live a normal life despite the fact that he sometimes turns into a sheepdog.
Title: The Shaggy Dog
Writer: Cormac Wibberley (screenplay), Marianne Wibberley (screenplay), Geoff Rodkey (screenplay), Jack Amiel (screenplay), Michael Begler (screenplay), Bill Walsh (earlier screenplay "The Shaggy Dog"), Lillie Hayward (earlier screenplay "The Shaggy Dog"), Don Tait (earlier screenplay "The Shaggy D.A.")
tomatoConsensus: This Disney retread has neither inspiration nor originality, but may please moviegoers under the age of ten.

Actors: Sook-Yin Lee, Paul Dawson, Lindsay Beamish, PJ DeBoy

Title: Shortbus
tomatoConsensus: The sex may be explicit, but Mitchell integrates it into the characters' lives and serves the whole story up with a generous dose of sweetness and wit.

Actors: Radha Mitchell, Sean Bean, Laurie Holden, Deborah Kara Unger
Plot: A woman goes in search for her daughter, within the confines of a strange, desolate town called Silent Hill. Based on the video game.
Title: Silent Hill
tomatoConsensus: Silent Hill is visually impressive, but as with many video game adaptations, it's plagued by inane dialogue, a muddled plot, and an overlong runtime.

Actors: Don Thompson, Nathan Fillion, Gregg Henry, Xantha Radley
Plot: A small town is taken over by an alien plague, turning residents into zombies and all forms of mutant monsters.
Title: Slither
tomatoConsensus: A slimy, rotten B-movie homage oozing with affection for low-budget horror films, Slither is a tale of creepy crawly little beasts that invade Smalltown, USA. Equally creepy and funny, critics say it's one of the most enjoyable of its type in years -- if you've got the stomach for this sort of thing. Slither is a wicked good time: it'll make you squirm -- when you're not busting a gut laughing.

Actors: Samuel L. Jackson, Julianna Margulies, Nathan Phillips, Rachel Blanchard
Plot: An FBI agent takes on a plane full of deadly and poisonous snakes, deliberately released to kill a witness being flown from Honolulu to Los Angeles to testify against a mob boss.
Title: Snakes on a Plane
Writer: John Heffernan (screenplay), Sebastian Gutierrez (screenplay), David Dalessandro (story)
tomatoConsensus: Snakes on a Plane lives up to its title, featuring snakes on a plane. It isn't perfect, but then again, it doesn't need to be.

Actors: Sanaa Lathan, Fuzzy Fantabulous, Katharine Towne, Stanley DeSantis
Plot: Kenya McQueen, an accountant finds love in the most unexpected place when she agrees to go on a blind date with Brian Kelly, a sexy and free-spirited landscaper.
Title: Something New
tomatoConsensus: Something New tackles serious questions about race and interracial relationships with genuine appeal and an alluring romance that develops as naturally as the plot.

Actors: Jon Foster, Samaire Armstrong, Frankie Muniz, Jimmi Simpson
Plot: For a group of teens, the answer to the mysterious death of their old friend lies within the world of an online video game based on the true story of an ancient noblewoman known as the Blood Countess.
Title: Stay Alive
tomatoConsensus: A by-the-numbers teen horror flick, Stay Alive fails to exploit its premise for any real scares.

Actors: Channing Tatum, Jenna Dewan-Tatum, Damaine Radcliff, De'Shawn Washington
Plot: Tyler Gage receives the opportunity of a lifetime after vandalizing a performing arts school, gaining him the chance to earn a scholarship and dance with an up and coming dancer, Nora.
Title: Step Up
tomatoConsensus: This trite teen romance has too little plot and not enough dancing.

Actors: Jeff Bridges, Missy Peregrym, Vanessa Lengies, Nikki SooHoo
Plot: After a run-in with the law, Haley Graham (Missy Peregrym) is forced to return to the world from which she fled some years ago. Enrolled in an elite gymnastics program run by the legendary Burt Vickerman (Jeff Bridges), Haley's rebellious attitude gives way to something that just might be called team spirit.
Title: Stick It
tomatoConsensus: Director Jessica Bendinger is unable to transfer her winning Bring It On formula to the world of gymnastics, despite Missy Peregrym's strong lead performance.

Actors: Will Ferrell, William Dick, Guy Massey, Martha Espinoza
Awards: Nominated for 1 Golden Globe. Another 3 wins & 11 nominations.
Plot: An IRS auditor suddenly finds himself the subject of narration only he can hear: narration that begins to affect his entire life, from his work, to his love-interest, to his death.
Title: Stranger Than Fiction
tomatoConsensus: A fun, whimsical tale about an office drone trying to save his life from his narrator, Stranger Than Fiction features a subdued performances from Will Ferrell that contributes mightily to its quirky, mind-bending affect.

Actors: Brandon Routh, Kate Bosworth, Kevin Spacey, James Marsden
Awards: Nominated for 1 Oscar. Another 10 wins & 22 nominations.
Plot: After a long visit to the lost remains of the planet Krypton, the Man of Steel returns to Earth to become the people's savior once again and reclaim the love of Lois Lane.
Title: Superman Returns
Writer: Michael Dougherty (screenplay), Dan Harris (screenplay), Bryan Singer (story), Jerry Siegel (characters), Joe Shuster (characters)
tomatoConsensus: Bryan Singer's reverent and visually decadent adaptation gives the Man of Steel welcome emotional complexity. The result: a satisfying stick-to-your-ribs adaptation.

Actors: Antonio Banderas, Yaya Alafia, Rob Brown, Alfre Woodard
Plot: The real story of a dance teacher who believed in the talent of a group of problem kids.
Title: Take the Lead
tomatoConsensus: Banderas is charismatic in the lead, and the dance sequences are captivating, but the story is too familiar and predictable.

Actors: Will Ferrell, John C. Reilly, Sacha Baron Cohen, Gary Cole
Plot: #1 NASCAR driver Ricky Bobby stays atop the heap thanks to a pact with his best friend and teammate, Cal Naughton, Jr. But when a French Formula One driver, makes his way up the ladder, Ricky Bobby's talent and devotion are put to the test.
Title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby
tomatoConsensus: Though it occasionally stalls, Talladega Nights' mix of satire, clever gags, and excellent ensemble performances put it squarely in the winner's circle.

Actors: Josh Duhamel, Melissa George, Olivia Wilde, Desmond Askew
Plot: A group of young backpackers' vacation turns sour when a bus accident leaves them marooned in a remote Brazilian rural area that holds an ominous secret.
Title: Turistas
tomatoConsensus: Beautiful scenery and cinematography can't save Turistas from its wooden acting and stale and predictable plot.

Actors: Milla Jovovich, Cameron Bright, Nick Chinlund, Sebastien Andrieu
Plot: A beautiful hemophage infected with a virus that gives her superhuman powers has to protect a boy in a futuristic world, who is thought to be carrying antigens that would destroy all hemophages.
Title: Ultraviolet
tomatoConsensus: An incomprehensible and forgettable sci-fi thriller, Ultraviolet is inept in every regard.

Actors: Lewis Black, Wilmer Valderrama, Tyler James Williams, Dyllan Christopher
Plot: A group of unaccompanied minors bond while snowed in at the midwestern Hoover International Airport during the holiday season and ultimately create a makeshift holiday themselves.
Title: Unaccompanied Minors
tomatoConsensus: Unaccompanied Minors, while featuring credible performances by its mostly young cast, is simply a rehash of other, funnier movies.

Actors: J.J. Johnson, Gary Commock, Polly Adams, Opal Alladin
Awards: Nominated for 2 Oscars. Another 24 wins & 21 nominations.
Plot: A real time account of the events on United Flight 93, one of the planes hijacked on 9/11 that crashed near Shanksville, Pennsylvania when passengers foiled the terrorist plot.
Title: United 93
tomatoConsensus: Potent and sobering, United 93 is even more gut-wrenching because the outcome is already known. While difficult to watch, director Paul Greengrass' film has been made with skill and treats the subject matter with respect, never resorting to the aggrandizement of which Hollywood has sometimes been accused. Especially effective is the cast of mostly unknown actors, who portray the passengers of the doomed flight as ordinary people who respond with bravery to extraordinary circumstances.

Actors: Kal Penn, Lauren Cohan, Daniel Percival, Glen Barry
Plot: Taj Mahal Badalandabad leaves Coolidge College behind for the halls of Camford University in England, where he looks to continue his education, and teach an uptight student how to make the most out of her academic career.
Title: Van Wilder 2: The Rise of Taj
Writer: David Drew Gallagher, Brent Goldberg (characters), David Wagner (characters)
tomatoConsensus: A low-brow comedy, minus the comedy.

Actors: Peter O'Toole, Leslie Phillips, Beatrice Savoretti, Philip Fox
Awards: Nominated for 1 Oscar. Another 3 wins & 17 nominations.
Plot: Life for a pair of veteran actors gets turned upside down after they meet a brash teenager.
Title: Venus
tomatoConsensus: Audiences may attend to witness Peter O'Toole's Oscar-worthy performance, but they'll also be treated to a humane, tender exploration of maturing with both dignity and irreverence.

Actors: Penélope Cruz, Carmen Maura, Lola Dueñas, Blanca Portillo
Awards: Nominated for 1 Oscar. Another 55 wins & 53 nominations.
Plot: After her death, a mother returns to her home town in order to fix the situations she couldn't resolve during her life.
Title: Volver
tomatoConsensus: Volver catches director Pedro Almodovar and star Penelope Cruz at the peak of their respective powers, in service of a layered, thought-provoking film. This magical tragicomic melodrama may be Almodovar's most restrained work to date, but it still features his trademarks: a strong attention to color and detail, a celebration of the trials and tribulations of women, and, of course, the inestimable Carmen Maura. The lovely Penelope Cruz hasn't shone more brightly as she does here.

Actors: Tyrese Gibson, Shawn Parr, Henry Hunter Hall, Johnny C. Pruitt
Plot: An ex-convict (Tyrese) gets tangled up with a gang after his car is hijacked with his son inside.
Title: Waist Deep
Writer: Vondie Curtis-Hall (screenplay), Darin Scott (screenplay), Michael Mahern (story)
tomatoConsensus: A well-meaning B-movie that suffers from a cliche-ridden script and poorly drawn characters that fail to inspire much sympathy.

Actors: Matthew McConaughey, Matthew Fox, Anthony Mackie, David Strathairn
Plot: When a plane crash claims the lives of members of the Marshall University football team and some of its fans, the team's new coach and his surviving players try to keep the football program alive.
Title: We Are Marshall
Writer: Jamie Linden (screenplay), Cory Helms (story), Jamie Linden (story)
tomatoConsensus: Matthew McConaughey almost runs We Are Marshall to the end zone, but can't stop it from taking the easy, feel-good route in memorializing this historic event in American sports.

Actors: Camilla Belle, Tommy Flanagan, Katie Cassidy, Tessa Thompson
Plot: During an otherwise routine babysitting gig, a high-school student is harassed by an increasingly threatening prank caller.
Title: When a Stranger Calls
Writer: Jake Wade Wall (screenplay), Steve Feke, Fred Walton
tomatoConsensus: What's fitting punishment for running up the phone bill? Why have that person baby sit; that'll teach them. Or better yet, make that person through this poorly acted, fright-free remake of the 1979 movie of the same name. Camilla Belle is a looker, but she got nothing on Carol Kane, the actress who originally played the part, when it comes to range. The final straw is that the payoff isn't worth the tedium that comes before. Just hang up on this one.

Actors: Martin Sheen, Reverend Gadget, Dave Barthmuss, Ed Begley Jr.
Plot: A documentary that investigates the birth and death of the electric car, as well as the role of renewable energy and sustainable living in the future.
Title: Who Killed the Electric Car?
tomatoConsensus: A searing indictment of big business and greed, Who Killed The Electric Car? is a well-tuned doc that simultaneously entertains and enrages.

Actors: Kiefer Sutherland, James Belushi, Eddie Izzard, Janeane Garofalo
Plot: An adolescent lion is accidentally shipped from the New York Zoo to Africa. Now running free, his zoo pals must put aside their differences to help bring him back.
Title: The Wild
Writer: Ed Decter (screenplay), John J. Strauss (screenplay), Mark Gibson (screenplay), Philip Halprin (screenplay), Mark Gibson (story), Philip Halprin (story), Bill Wolkoff (additional story material), David Collard (additional story material), Matt Lopez (additional story material), Lloyd Taylor (additional story material), Steve 'Spaz' Williams (additional story material)
tomatoConsensus: With a rehashed plot and unimpressive animation, there's nothing wild about The Wild.

Actors: Will Shortz, Merl Reagle, Tyler Hinman, Trip Payne
Plot: An in-depth look at The New York Times' long-time crossword puzzle editor Will Shortz and his loyal fan base.
Title: Wordplay
tomatoConsensus: You see them hunched over with their brows furrowed, folded newspaper in hand as they attempt to complete the crossword puzzle. This may even describe you. This ingeniously edited documentary introduces viewers to some of the more dedicated fans of this solitary pastime, none more well-known the puzzle editor for the New York Times, Will Shortz. This underground world provides a surprising amount of crowd-pleasing entertainment and suspense, especially at the annual crossword tournament. Didn't know there was one, did you?

Actors: Nicolas Cage, Maria Bello, Connor Paolo, Anthony Piccininni
Plot: Two Port Authority police officers become trapped under the rubble of the World Trade Center.
Title: World Trade Center
Writer: Andrea Berloff, John McLoughlin (true story), Donna McLoughlin (true story), William Jimeno (true story), Allison Jimeno (true story)
tomatoConsensus: As a visually stunning tribute to lives lost in tragedy, World Trade Center succeeds unequivocally, and it is more politically muted than many of Stone's other works.

Actors: Owen Wilson, Kate Hudson, Matt Dillon, Michael Douglas
Plot: A best man (Wilson) stays on as a houseguest with the newlyweds, much to the couple's annoyance.
Title: You, Me and Dupree
tomatoConsensus: A rather generic entry into the arrested development subgenre, with themes borrowed from other more successful and funnier films. Dupree wears out its welcome.

Actors: Tim Allen, Courteney Cox, Chevy Chase, Spencer Breslin
Plot: Former superhero Jack is called back to work to transform an unlikely group of ragtag kids into superheroes at a private Academy.
Title: Zoom
Writer: Adam Rifkin (screenplay), David Berenbaum (screenplay), Jason Lethcoe (novel)
tomatoConsensus: Lacking the punch and good cheer of The Incredibles and Sky High, Zoom is a dull and laugh-free affair.

Actors: John Cusack, Paul Birchard, Margot Leicester, Walter Lewis
Plot: A man who specializes in debunking paranormal occurrences checks into the fabled room 1408 in the Dolphin Hotel. Soon after settling in, he confronts genuine terror.
Writer: Matt Greenberg (screenplay), Scott Alexander (screenplay), Larry Karaszewski (screenplay), Stephen King (short story)
tomatoConsensus: Relying on psychological tension rather than overt violence and gore, 1408 is a genuinely creepy thriller with a strong lead performance by John Cusack.

Actors: Adam Goldberg, Julie Delpy, Daniel Brühl, Marie Pillet
Plot: Marion and Jack try to rekindle their relationship with a visit to Paris, home of Marion's parents -- and several of her ex-boyfriends.
Title: 2 Days in Paris
tomatoConsensus: Delpy proves not only to be an adept actress, but makes her mark as a writer and director in this thought-provoking comedy that breaks the romantic comedy mold.

Actors: Robert Carlyle, Rose Byrne, Jeremy Renner, Harold Perrineau
Plot: Six months after the rage virus was inflicted on the population of Great Britain, the US Army helps to secure a small area of London for the survivors to repopulate and start again. But not everything goes to plan.
Title: 28 Weeks Later
Writer: Rowan Joffe (screenplay), Juan Carlos Fresnadillo (screenplay), Enrique López Lavigne (screenplay), Jesús Olmo (screenplay)
tomatoConsensus: While 28 Weeks Later lacks the humanism that made 28 Days Later a classic, it's made up with fantastic atmosphere and punchy direction.

Actors: Josh Hartnett, Melissa George, Danny Huston, Ben Foster
Plot: After an Alaskan town is plunged into darkness for a month, it is attacked by a bloodthirsty gang of vampires.
Title: 30 Days of Night
Writer: Steve Niles (screenplay), Stuart Beattie (screenplay), Brian Nelson (screenplay), Steve Niles (comic), Ben Templesmith (comic)
tomatoConsensus: While 30 Days of Night offers a few thrills, it ultimately succumbs to erratic execution.

Actors: Gerard Butler, Lena Headey, Dominic West, David Wenham
Plot: King Leonidas and a force of 300 men fight the Persians at Thermopylae in 480 B.C.
Writer: Zack Snyder (screenplay), Kurt Johnstad (screenplay), Michael Gordon (screenplay), Frank Miller (graphic novel), Lynn Varley (graphic novel)
tomatoConsensus: A simple-minded but visually exciting experience, full of blood, violence, and ready-made movie quotes.

Actors: Russell Crowe, Christian Bale, Logan Lerman, Dallas Roberts
Awards: Nominated for 2 Oscars. Another 6 wins & 19 nominations.
Plot: A small-time rancher agrees to hold a captured outlaw who's awaiting a train to go to court in Yuma. A battle of wills ensues as the outlaw tries to psych out the rancher.
Title: 3:10 to Yuma
Writer: Halsted Welles (screenplay), Michael Brandt (screenplay), Derek Haas (screenplay), Elmore Leonard (short story)
tomatoConsensus: This remake of a classic Western improves on the original, thanks to fiery performances from Russell Crowe and Christian Bale as well as sharp direction from James Mangold.

Actors: Evan Rachel Wood, Jim Sturgess, Joe Anderson, Dana Fuchs
Awards: Nominated for 1 Oscar. Another 1 win & 10 nominations.
Plot: The music of the Beatles and the Vietnam War form the backdrop for the romance between an upper-class American girl and a poor Liverpudlian artist.
Title: Across the Universe
Writer: Dick Clement (screenplay), Ian La Frenais (screenplay), Julie Taymor (story)
tomatoConsensus: Psychedelic musical numbers can't mask Across the Universe's clich?d love story and uninteresting characters.

Actors: Mads Mikkelsen, Neeral Mulchandani, Tanya Sharma, Swini Khara
Awards: Nominated for 1 Oscar. Another 10 wins & 16 nominations.
Plot: A manager of an orphanage in India is sent to Copenhagen, Denmark, where he discovers a life-altering family secret.
Title: After the Wedding
tomatoConsensus: The cast brings After the Wedding's melodramatic script to life, creating a movie that is emotionally raw and satisfying.

Actors: Ioan Gruffudd, Romola Garai, Benedict Cumberbatch, Albert Finney
Plot: The idealist William Wilberforce maneuvers his way through Parliament, endeavoring to end the British transatlantic slave trade.
Title: Amazing Grace
tomatoConsensus: Amazing Grace is your quintessential historical biopic: stately, noble, and with plenty of electrifying performances.

Actors: Denzel Washington, Russell Crowe, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Josh Brolin
Awards: Nominated for 2 Oscars. Another 9 wins & 30 nominations.
Plot: In 1970s America, a detective works to bring down the drug empire of Frank Lucas, a heroin kingpin from Manhattan, who is smuggling the drug into the country from the Far East.
Title: American Gangster
tomatoConsensus: American Gangster is a gritty and entertaining throwback to classic gangster films, with its lead performers firing on all cylinders.

Actors: Bruce Willis, Matthew Barry, Emile Hirsch, Fernando Vargas
Plot: A drama based on the life of Jesse James Hollywood, a drug dealer who became one of the youngest men ever to be on the FBI's most wanted list.
Title: Alpha Dog
tomatoConsensus: A glossy yet unflinching portrait of violent, hedonistic teenagers. Bruce Willis and Sharon Stone chew the scenery, while Justin Timberlake gives a noteworthy performance.

Actors: Queen Latifah, Katrina Agate, Zain Ali, Preston Bailey
Plot: Two narratives -- the life cycle of a mother walrus and her calf, and the life of a polar bear and her cubs -- are used to illustrate the harsh realities of existence in the Arctic.
Title: Arctic Tale
Writer: Linda Woolverton (narration), Mose Richards (narration), Kristin Gore (narration)
tomatoConsensus: Arctic Tale features breathtaking nature cinematography, but is undone by its over-cutesy narration.

Actors: Ice Cube, Nia Long, John C. McGinley, LeNae Allen
Plot: Newlyweds Nick (Ice Cube) and Suzanne (Long) decide to move to the suburbs to provide a better life for their two kids. But their idea of a dream home is disturbed by a contractor (McGinley) with a bizarre approach to business.
Title: Are We Done Yet?
Writer: Hank Nelken (screenplay), Steven Gary Banks (characters), Claudia Grazioso (characters), Norman Panama (screenplay), Melvin Frank (screenplay)
tomatoConsensus: Are We Done Yet? plays it way too safe with generic slapstick and uninspired domestic foibles.

Actors: Brad Pitt, Mary-Louise Parker, Brooklynn Proulx, Dustin Bollinger
Awards: Nominated for 2 Oscars. Another 18 wins & 24 nominations.
Plot: Robert Ford, who's idolized Jesse James since childhood, tries hard to join the reforming gang of the Missouri outlaw, but gradually becomes resentful of the bandit leader.
Title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
tomatoConsensus: On the strength of its two lead performances Assassination is an expertly crafted period piece, and an insightful look at one of the enduring figures of American lore.

Actors: Billy Bob Thornton, Virginia Madsen, Max Thieriot, Jasper Polish
Plot: A NASA astronaut (Thornton), forced to retire years earlier so he could save his family farm, has never given up his dream of space travel and looks to build his own rocket, despite the government's threats to stop him.
Title: The Astronaut Farmer
tomatoConsensus: The Astronaut Farmer is a charming, inspirational drama that successfully avoids modern cinematic cliches while appealing to the optimistic dreamer in all of us.

Actors: Saoirse Ronan, Ailidh Mackay, Brenda Blethyn, Julia West
Plot: Fledgling writer Briony Tallis, as a 13-year-old, irrevocably changes the course of several lives when she accuses her older sister's lover of a crime he did not commit. Based on the British romance novel by Ian McEwan.
Title: Atonement
tomatoConsensus: Atonement features strong performances, brilliant cinematography, and a unique score. Featuring deft performances from James MacAvoy and Keira Knightley, it's a successful adaptation of Ian McEwan's novel.

Actors: Freddie Highmore, Keri Russell, Jonathan Rhys Meyers, Terrence Howard
Awards: Nominated for 1 Oscar. Another 4 wins & 9 nominations.
Plot: A drama with fairy tale elements, where an orphaned musical prodigy uses his gift as a clue to finding his birth parents.
Title: August Rush
Writer: Nick Castle (screenplay), James V. Hart (screenplay), Paul Castro (story)
tomatoConsensus: Though featuring a talented cast, August Rush cannot overcome the flimsy direction and schmaltzy plot.

Actors: Valérie Lemercier, Cécile De France, Albert Dupontel, Claude Brasseur
Plot: A young woman arrives in Paris where she finds a job as a waitress in bar next on Avenue Montaigne that caters to the surrounding theaters and the wealthy inhabitants of the area. She will meet a pianist, a famous actress and a great art collector, and become acquainted with the "luxurious" world her grandmother has told her about since her childhood.
Title: Avenue Montaigne
Writer: Danièle Thompson (screenplay), Christopher Thompson (screenplay), Danièle Thompson (dialogue)
tomatoConsensus: A cute and bubbly French comedy that carries no deeper lessons or agendas than to have a little fun for 90 minutes.

Actors: Hayden Christensen, Jessica Alba, Terrence Howard, Lena Olin
Plot: The story focuses on a man who suffers "anesthetic awareness" and finds himself awake and aware, but paralyzed, during heart surgery. His mother must wrestle with her own demons as a drama unfolds around them, while trying to unfold the story hidden behind her son's young wife.
Title: Awake
tomatoConsensus: Awake has an interesting premise but would have benefited from tighter performances and more efficient direction and editing.

Actors: Gordon Pinsent, Stacey LaBerge, Julie Christie, Olympia Dukakis
Awards: Nominated for 2 Oscars. Another 42 wins & 18 nominations.
Plot: A man coping with the institutionalization of his wife because of Alzheimer's disease faces an epiphany when she transfers her affections to another man, Aubrey, a wheelchair-bound mute who also is a patient at the nursing home.
Title: Away from Her
Writer: Sarah Polley, Alice Munro (short story "The Bear Came Over the Mountain")
tomatoConsensus: An accomplished directorial debut by Sarah Polley, Away From Her is a touching exploration of the effects of Alzheimer's, in which the tender wisdom of Polley's script is beautifully complemented by a wonderful performance from Julie Christie.

Actors: Dan Fogler, Christopher Walken, George Lopez, Maggie Q
Plot: Down-and-out former professional ping-pong phenom, Randy Daytona, is sucked into a maelstrom when FBI Agent Ernie Rodriguez recruits him for a secret mission. Randy is determined to bounce back and win, and to smoke out his father's killer -- arch-fiend Feng.
Title: Balls of Fury
tomatoConsensus: Tasteless, yet harmless, Balls of Fury nevertheless fails to generate enough laughs despite its lowbrow intentions.

Actors: Diane Keaton, Mandy Moore, Gabriel Macht, Tom Everett Scott
Plot: A meddling mother tries to set her daughter up with the right man so her kid won't follow in her footsteps.
Title: Because I Said So
tomatoConsensus: Overly reliant on caricatures and lacking any human insight, Because I Said So is an unfunny, cliche-ridden mess.

Actors: Anne Hathaway, James McAvoy, Julie Walters, James Cromwell
Plot: A biographical portrait of a pre-fame Jane Austen and her romance with a young Irishman.
Title: Becoming Jane
